subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Experiment 20100710 - RESULTS!
author: Frank Sumption
full_text:
So you're not going to count my prediction as accurate? Or at least a big
DAH!

 So go out in the world and claim you thoroughly debunked spirit's
existance.



 F-S

On Wed, Jul 14, 2010 at 12:00 PM, rasterer <rasterer@yahoo.com> wrote:

>
>
>
> Thanks again for everyone who participated! I admire your courage and
> motivation to try different methods, see what works, and try to improve
> everyone's understanding of EVP-ITC.
>
> If you recall, on 7/10/2010 I placed an object on top of my computer
> monitor, right in front of me, and left it there until today, 7/14/2010,
> noon Denver time. The experiment was for participants to determine what it
> was. Vague or partial answers wouldn't be counted (for example, just colors,
> shapes, sizes, what it's made of, etc): we're looking for what it is.
> Participants could use their ghost boxes, EVP recorders, or I suppose any
> other means they chose.
>
> In order to keep me honest, I took a picture of the object at the start of
> the experiment and loaded it to the Files section (RJ folder) of this group.
> If you can follow the link, it is here:
>
> http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/files/RJ/RJ.20100710.1.zip
>
> The idea was that you could download the file at the beginning of the test,
> and 'keep it safe' on your computer. Then at the end of the test, I would
> release the password so you could reveal the contents of the file. That way,
> you were in control of the original image during the entire test, not me.
>
> The password for that file is: 123BlastOff
> Instructions, if you need them, are also in that RJ folder.
>
> And if you did not care to download the zip file before the test, I will
> post the final image there too.
>
> So to the results:
>
> Number of participants: 5
> Total tries: 8
> Ambiguous answers: 0
> Correct answers: 0
>
> Object: A radio
> Uzipped picture:
> http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/files/RJ/RJ.20100710.1.JPG
>
> So what do the results mean? All that we can really agree on from this
> experiment is that no participant, with whatever theories or methods or
> technology they used, was able to correctly determine the object. We can't
> say those theories or methods or technologies never work. Just as we can't
> say they do. Just that, for whatever reason, they did not work this time.
> Readers can take the results, use them to improve or change their methods,
> or keep doing what they're doing.
>
> If anyone has any observations, comments, or ideas for improvement, let me
> know. I hope to get a new experiment up and running soon. Since there wasn't
> much participation Mon-Wed, I think the next experiment will be arranged to
> mostly span the weekends.
>
> Again, thanks to everyone who participated in this first experiment.
>
> 
>

So you' e no going o coun my p edic ion as accu a e? O a leas a big DAH!
 
 So go ou in he wo ld and claim you ho oughly debunked spi i 's exis ance.
 
 
 
 F-S
